bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Robert P. Cooke, February 28, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg sends Cooke copies of the first two paintings in the "Pioneers of American Medicine" series. Kellogg requests permission to contact Cooke again in order to obtain data for the next painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Robert P. Cooke, February 28, 1941
div1.opener:
Dr. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
EXECUTIVE
February 28, 1941.
Dr. Robert P. Cooke,
State Dept. of Health,
Lexington-Rockbridge Health Dept.
Lexington, Va.
Dear Dr. Cooke:
div1.p:
Yesterday I placed in the mail copies of the first two
paintings in John Wyeth & Brother's series “Pioneers of
American Medicine” in anticipation of writing you about
the next painting in the series. It will be called
“The Conquest of Yellow Fever” and Mr. Dean Cornwell, the
artist, has been working on preliminary sketches for
some months past.

A couple of weeks ago I was in Rochester, Minn. and had
two fine talks with Dr. P.F. Hench at the Mayo Clinic, who
you know is vitally interested in the yellow fever story.
Among others, he suggested that I write you for helpful
data. Right at the moment I have no specific questions
which I wish to ask you but you may be hearing from me
in the very near future. I merely wanted this letter
to explain the reason for my sending the prints which
have been mailed under separate cover.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, George A. Kellogg
